comments:
Build ID: 20060926

I have a big dev workspace, where an infinite loop of container initialization occurs. It takes almost all CPU in main thread, making further progress almost impossible.

First symptom usually is that console (when build trace is enabled) gets filled with build request=true.

As John observed:
It looks like bug 146246, but the big difference this time is that it always says "needsBuild: true".
This message appears at the end of a workspace runnable when the tree has been changed.
So, it looks like the main thread is continuously running many workspace runnables.
Also, there is no build happening in the stack trace. There is a snapshot occurring however.The snapshot is not surprising, since we kick that off after every 100 workspace operations - in this case it looks like there are hundreds of operations happening every few seconds - so it's probably continually doing a workspace snapshot.
That would be part of the cause of the high CPU.
It looks like all other threads are inactive - just the main thread, and snapshot job.
I wonder if it will eventually finish if you leave it ?


Well, I left it playing for 6hours, and it didn't improve. Had to kill the workspace. Restarting it shows the same problem over and over again.

Today, we tried one different thing. Start workspace in a debug runtime workbench.
We noticed that during the initialization of a PDE container, we never get back the value for the container we asked for.

e.g. asking for project P1 PDE container, the initializer sets P2 container instead. 

It seems the PDE model is inconsistent causing the issue in the end. Maybe we should add protection against such a case. Jerome pls fork a separate bug to make sure we are resilient (avoid looping forever).

Wassim - I am going to zip my workspace, it is big (1.7GB expanded...). You should be able to debug it on a 3.3 client. Will send you access info by email.

The corruption manifested itself with:
  PDECore.getDefault().getModelManager().findEntry(project);
that would return an inconsistent ModelEntry. 

Its 'id' was the project P1 that was asked for, however its 'fWorkspaceModel' underlying resource was the manifest.mf of project P2.

Deleting the offending project (com.i*.t*.analysis.* projects) and re-checking them out from repository seems to fix the problem.

(In reply to comment #5)
> It seems the PDE model is inconsistent causing the issue in the end. Maybe we

Entered bug 160005

OK, figured it out.  Two projects has the same bundle symbolic name.  Each workspace model should have a IModelEntry (this keeps track of the workspace model, external model, and the PDE classpath container).  We find all the plug-in projects then create ModelEntries for each.  The ModelEntries are then stored by bundle-symbolic name.  

A ModelEntry can have only one workspace model, since PDE does not support multiple plug-ins with same bundle-symbolic name.  So when we initialize a project's classpath container, we find its bundle-symbolic name.  We then find the corresponding ModelEntry.  We then update the classpath container in the ModelEntry object.  But in this case, since two projects had the same bundle-symbolic name, they both resolved to the same ModelEntry.  

For instance, say P1 and P2 both have the bundle-symbolicName P1.  We created a ModelEntry with the bundle-SymbolicName P1 and set the workspace project to P1.  But since P2 has the same bundle-SymbolicName, we then set the ModelEntry for the id P1, to the P2 workspace project.  When we initialized project P1, we found the bundle-symbolicName and found the corresponding ModelEntry (which contained a reference to P2).  We then updated the classpath container for the workspace project specified in the ModelEntry (P2).  Therefore, every time we tried to initialize P1, we kept initializing P2 instead.

The fix is simple.  When initializing the classpath container, we have an IProject which represents the project getting initialized.  Once we get the ModelEntry back, we check to make sure the workspace project it references is the same as the project we are trying to initialize.  If they don't match, we don't do anything which will leave the container uninitialized (but will stop infinite loops).  Note, this will leave the container "unbounded".  I am not sure if this is the exact behavior we want, but it will tell the user they have a Plug-in Dependency classpath container issue.

traces.message: D:\jazz\sdk\jazz\eclipse\plugins\com.ibm.magnolia.extension_0.4.0.I20060912-0804\plugin.xml (The system cannot find the path specified)
